direction.raw_text: . MANSION FLAT, LONDON - DAY 2 A neat, well-appointed flat, tastefully decorated. Framed against a large window which looks out over the city, an elegant woman in her 70's: EVELYN GREENSLADE. She's on the phone, on hold. On the desk in front of her is a brand new laptop computer; the screen reads 'Getting Started ...'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for your patience. Your call is important to us. We will be with you shortly. Evelyn's patience is strained nonetheless. She taps her fingers on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) (ON PHONE) Thank you for your patience. Your call is - A slightly-accented voice finally interrupts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Greenslade, thank you for WAITING -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, now if you could stay on the phone for a moment and talk to me, just talk to me. I'm not even clear, I don't actually understand what it is I'm trying to order. Is wireless the same as wi-fi? And what do either of them have to do with broadband?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Greenslade, since the account is not in your name, before we can make any changes we need to speak to the account holder. Can I please talk to the account holder?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm asking if I can speak to the account holder. Before we can make any changes -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't talk to him, no. (BEAT) He's dead. He died. There's only me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CORRIDOR/JUDGES CHAMBERS. INNS OF COURT - NIGHT 3 GILES, a judge in full wig and robes, moves quickly down a corridor. He passes other judges, going the opposite way. He arrives at the office of GRAHAM DASHWOOD, goes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is at his desk. His robes are on a hanger, his wig is on a stand beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CORRIDOR. INNS OF COURT - NIGHT 4 Moments later. Graham and Giles walk down the corridor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bloody retirement parties. Hard cheese, soft wine, and endless speeches. Why do people do that? No one ever said about any kind of party: it was a wonderful occasion, just a shame that the speeches were so short.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: it'll be you one day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One day very soon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've been saying that for years. They walk into a large room, full of lawyers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HALL. INNS OF COURT - CONTINUOUS 4A At one end of the hall, a very old JUDGE is giving a very dull speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An occasion such as this leads one to cast ones mind back to the days when I first entered my pupillage. I had the very good fortune of serving as a junior to Mr Justice Stancombe Graham's not listening any more. He's looking around the room. At the old, tired faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . the unwelcome news that I would transfer Chambers, bringing to mind the old adage a fronte praecipitium, a tergo 1upi Everything seems to slow down, the judge's mouth moving more and more sluggishly, though his voice remains the same. The effect is strange .. then the sound of laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the day. Everyone looks round at him. He's almost as surprised as they are that he's spoken out loud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Graham?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the day. He turns and walks out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOSPITAL - DAY 5 Staff bustle around a busy A & E ward. MURIEL lies on a bed in the corridor. The Head Nurse, KAREN, rushes past.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen, young lady. I want a cup of tea, and I want it now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The trolley will be along shortly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How hard d'you have to fall down before you get some proper attention? Hours I've been lying here, and not a single doctor has come to see me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now that's not quite true, is it Mrs Donnelly? (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A doctor did try and examine you, and you sent him away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That one? She looks up to the far end of the ward, where a doctor is washing his hands. He's black.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can wash all he likes, that colour's not coming out. I want an English doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An English doctor? Why didn't you say so? I'll get one right away. She goes away, comes back moments later with a tall, handsome doctor. The bad news for Muriel is
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Dr Ghujarapartidar. And this is Mrs Donnelly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NEW HOUSING ESTATE - DAY 5A A crescent of identical bungalows, part of a brand new retirement facility. A mobility scooter carrying an elderly resident trundles down the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) .. with an unlimited range of leisure opportunities just a stone's throw away...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NEW HOUSING DEVELOPMENT - DAY 6 A young estate agent, EVAN, is showing DOUGLAS and JEAN around a very small, and very beige bungalow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So as I say, what you're looking at here is very competitively priced, you can't get better value for your grey pound. Another little feature, not necessary right now, but give it a couple of years (POINTS) . rails on the walls to help you get around, and down here, a panic button in case of a sudden fall, brings the Warden running.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if we fell somewhere else?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's just that we might not manage to plan our sudden fall in the exact corner where the button is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. As I say - 5.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And would it be possible to get the rail to go through the middle of the room as well?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To help us get across, not just around?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could we have a moment, please? Thanks. Thanks so much. Evan goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thirty years in the Civil Service and this is all we can afford?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would it help if I apologized again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. But try it anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BAR - NIGHT 7 JUDITH (40ish) is sitting opposite someone. We don't see whom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then after that I worked as a systems analyst for a few years but I just found it so dull, what I really wanted was to do something that was more creative, that matched my ... (BEAT) I'm sorry. On the form they asked for our age bracket, and the age we wanted to meet . and in both cases I ticked 35-45. Now we see the man she's talking to. It's NORMAN. He's dapper, nice looking. And at least 70.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right, yes. So did I. They're at a speed dating evening. Numbered tables, etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyway, don't stop. Something
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Early 40's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: D'you mean you were born in the early 40's?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Judy, I know what you're asking -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Judith.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Judith. And trust me, I've still got it. The bell goes; the signal for the women to get up and move along to the next table. Judith leaves without looking back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just can't find anyone that wants it. Another hopeful candidate arrives opposite Norman. And looks crestfallen at what's on offer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM/STAIRS/HALL. FAMILY HOUSE - DAY 8 MADGE is in her bedroom. She's arguing with her son-in-law
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Madge's suitcases are by the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is crazy. You're crazy. You can't just up and leave like this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And yet if you watch me, that's exactly what you'll see happen. She picks up her suitcases, heads out of the room. Madge's daughter JESSICA is on the landing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's going on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your mother's lost it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mother never had it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Talk to her. She doesn't listen to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody listens to you. She heads down the stairs. Craig and Jessica follow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's one of the great mysteries of life that someone so vibrant and fascinating as my daughter should choose to spend her life with this fraction of a man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I still don't understand what's going on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just asked her to babysit. And now she says she's leaving. They're at the bottom of the stairs. Jessica's children,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and KATIE, are watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you love babysitting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I loved it last night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We had pizza and stayed up late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the night before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We had Chinese and stayed up late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you don't go, tonight we could do a curry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's tempting, my darlings, but you know why I must leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to her parents) Being here is stopping her finding a husband.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another one?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bye Granny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't let the buggers get you down. Madge turns to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many husbands have you had, anyway? She turns back, smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Including my own? Then she's out of the front door, and heading for the taxi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mother? Mother!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TAXI - DAY 9 Moments later. Madge climbs into the back of the cab.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Name the place, darling. Where are you going? Madge smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have absolutely no idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MANSION FLAT - DAY 10 Evelyn, whom we saw earlier on the phone, is in the living room. Her son CHRISTOPHER is there. And her lawyer
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no other way There just isn't. Harold told us this three months ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'm afraid matters have only got worse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can't wait any longer. We need to put this flat on the market, and at least make a start at paying off Dad's debts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Christopher turns to Harold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've talked it through with Polly and the boys, and of course we all agreed. Ma will move in with us. HAROLD I think that's best, Evelyn. It's what Hugh would've wanted. They wait for confirmation from Evelyn. None comes. CHRISTOPHER Good. Settled. End of discussion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what your father used to say. CHRISTOPHER MA - EVELYN When there'd never really been any discussion at all. CHRISTOPHER I want to look after things for you. EVELYN Like he did for forty years CHRISTOPHER Yes. EVELYN And look how that turned out. She turns to Harold EVELYN (CONT'D) How can any of us know what Hugh would've wanted? And would he have seen fit to tell us anyway? (BEST) Obviously the flat has to be sold. (Best, then to Christopher) And you're very kind. And dear Polly. But no, I won't be coming to live with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOSPITAL - DAY 11 Muriel has now been transferred to a ward. She is listening to DR GHUJARAPARTIDAR.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You need a new hip, Mrs Donnelly. It's not a difficult operation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Easy for you to say, you're not having it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Regardless. You do need a new hip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not getting it from you. 2nd Green Revisions I0/01/11 10.

direction.raw_text: Not me personally, no.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not any of your lot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So when do I have the operation?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid you'll be on a waiting list for at least six months.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At my age, I can't plan that far ahead. I don't even buy green bananas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is another way. Our hospital trust is funding a new pilot scheme, that will enable us to out-source you to another hospital, where they can perform the procedure almost immediately, and at a fraction of the cost.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it local?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That depends how you define local.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVELYN'S FLAT/CHRISTOPHER'S OFFICE - NIGHT 12 Evelyn is on the phone to her son Christopher. They're both sitting at computers. Evelyn's new-found dexterity is impressive. Around Evelyn's room are packing boxes, some already full.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When did you get a computer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How far along is the progress bar? The strip at the bottom that tells you -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know what it is. What are you showing me anyway?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The webpage has come up. It's a picture of a beautiful old building. And underneath is written 'THE BEST EXOTIC MARIGOLD HOTEL'. As Christopher gapes in horror, he hears a mellifluous Indian voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Come and spend your autumn years in an Indian palace with the sophistication of an English country manor. Steeped in the tradition of the Raj, tucked away on the outskirts of Jaipur .'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INTERNET CAFE - DAY 13 The mellifluous tones continue. Madge mouths the words to herself as she scans the same web-page.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: it exudes historical ambience and is graced with breathtaking surroundings .'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SALON - DAY 14 Jean whom we earlier saw looking at the bungalow, is at the hairdressers. Her stylist ABI listens to her reading a computer printout for the same hotel. Which looks classy, elegant, and welcoming. Madge's voice bleeds into Jean's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Lofty terraces, open courtyards, domes, arches and canopied balconies transport one back in time.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wouldn't mind going there myself.

direction.raw_text: There won't be any golf courses.

direction.raw_text: How long have we known each other? And you've never once talked about India.

direction.raw_text: I want you to have this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you sure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Absolutely. There's a slight crack on the bottom. But I think you might know something about that already. Mrs Megson goes.

direction.raw_text: I used to live there. A long time ago.

direction.raw_text: . BASEMENT BEDSIT. EARLS COURT - DAY 17 A bedsit. Slightly down at heel, and sparsely furnished. Norman, whom we met speed dating, is talking to someone. We don't see who. Quietly, in the background, Radio 2 music from an old battery radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to go. I do. And I could say I wish you'd come, but I've never lied to you. We both know I need more than you can offer. We know that. Don't we? We see who's sitting in front of him. An ancient dachshund.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the dog) Don't make that face at me. Norman's Polish landlady, MRS JELLINEK, is at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to her dog) You. Upstairs. The dog hops off the chair, and leaves. Norman watches him go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Any warm clothes you have use for no more, I take them. And not forget to leave keys when you go. She leaves. Norman is left alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll miss you too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOUSING ESTATE - DAY 18 The district ambulance driver, JACKSON, is pushing Muriel in a wheelchair across a housing estate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know who'll be there, don't you? Indians. Loads of them, A sea of brown faces and black hearts, all greasy haired and reeking of spices. Never see one on their own, do you? No, becuase they hunt in packs. All the better to rob me blind and -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what? You can take it from here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're supposed to see me into my flat. That's what they said.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My wife is from Mumbai. He heads off. Muriel shouts after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No good moaning to me, mate. You married her! But he's gone. Muriel wheels herself on over the bumpy ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PASSENGER DROP-OFF. STANSTED AIRPORT - EVENING 19 A reluctant Christopher is pushing a trolley carrying Evelyn's cases to the terminal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're sure your tickets are in order?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They should be. The hotel paid for them. I'm sure they'd rather have us there than not. And its fantastically cheap for the first three months.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wonder why. They walk on in silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How will we know you're alright?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll call. They do have phones there, you know. Or you can just read my blog.

direction.raw_text: Your what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the interweb. You can log in whenever you like, read my news.

direction.raw_text: Could you please, before I go, say one thing that is supportive? Because I've never done anything like this before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Without Dad, you never did anything at all. And i don't think you'll be able to cope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well. I suppose we'll find out, won't we? They head into the building.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the connecting flight to Jaipur is first class too? The check-in girl nods, hands Madge back her passport.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I tell you, it's tough to get upgraded nowadays. I had to flirt so hard with the travel agent, it was practically phone sex.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SECURITY AREA. AIRPORT - EVENING 21 The light is fading.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Norman appears to be relishing a detailed search from a female Security Guard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on. Thorough as you like Muriel is waiting to collect her bag from the belt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'd like to take a look in this bag, Madam, if you don't mind. He lifts the bag onto a table. It's heavier than he thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) What you got in here anyway? He opens the bag, stares in astonishment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tips. Brown sauce. Ten jars of Marmite. Thirty one packets of Chocolate Hobnobs. Pickled onions. Pickled eggs. And pickle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No liquids on the plane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does that mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It means you can't take the pickled onions. Or the pickled eggs. (BEAT) The pickle's fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BOARDING GATE. AIRPORT - EVENING/NIGHT 22 The passengers from Flight 1045 to Delhi are seated at the gate, waiting to board. Muriel is wheeled up by an attendant and parked at the end of the only remaining row of empty chairs. Douglas and Jean are already sitting there. Jean smiles politely as Graham sits down a couple of seats away. Norman arrives, carrying his battery radio, sees an empty place between Jean and Madge, who is sitting at the end. He smiles knowingly at Madge as he sits. Finally Evelyn takes the only available space, between Graham and Douglas. And there the seven passengers wait patiently, unaware of their common fate. The sound of a jet engine, quiet at first, finally engulfs them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RUNWAY. INDIA - DAWN 23 The plane cruises down through a stunning sunset, and lands at Delhi Airport.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AIRPORT TERMINAL, DELHI - DAY 24 Evelyn, Douglas, Jean and Graham are descending on an escalator. Madge is a few steps up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Obviously one's read one's Kipling, but we view this as an opportunity to explore another culture, as well as making new friends. And a retired judge is just the class of guest one was hoping for, isn't it Douglas?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And is this your first time in India?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't seem like an experienced traveller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not. Although one has read one's guidebooks. Jean blinks. Evelyn and Graham share a smile. Douglas hides his. And Madge sees it all. As they head towards the baggage carousel, they're met by Muriel and Norman, emerging from the elevator. Norman is pushing Muriel's wheelchair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Norman Cousins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madge Hardcastle. A pleasure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Play your cards right, it could be. Madge stares at him. A voice comes over the tannoy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ladies and gentlemen, we regret to inform you that owing to bad weather, Flight 105 to Jaipur has been cancelled. The airline is happy to arrange
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AIRPORT. DELHI - DAY 25 Hours later. The airport is deserted, except for the Marigold Hotel party, who sit slumped and exhausted on another row of seats, with Muriel's wheelchair at the other end. After a moment, Graham says
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright. Plan B.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DELHI AIRPORT - DAY 26 Moments later. They're all moving briskly through the hi- tech, ultra-modern, beautifully air-conditioned building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course it's a good idea. Who can you trust if not a High Court Judge?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And this way we see more of the country. Norman is pushing Muriel's wheelchair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (leaning down, to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If anyone asks, say you're my mother. I don't want people to think we're together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In your dirty dreams.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Douglas, these are not words that often pass my lips, but you may actually be right. The country seems to be rather more civilised than one originally thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DELHI BUS STATION - EVENING 27 Moments later. Our heroes are in the middle of an extraordinary scene. Stifling heat, deafening noise; the chaos, the bustle, the grime, the crowds, the life. They're surrounded by taxi drivers, baggage handlers,beggars etc. All clamouring for their attention. Evelyn looks a little shocked. Jean is traumatized, a handkerchief to her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Graham, at the ticket booth, triumphantly holds up a fistful of tickets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shouting over the din) The bus will drop us in the centre of town. We can take tuk- tuks the rest of the way! They follow him through the hordes. And see their bus. It's absolutely rammed. People are practically hanging out of the windows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's not enough room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's time to prove the first and only rule of India: there's always room. He starts to fight his way to the door. Evelyn's at the back. She stops, for a moment, looks around her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What larks, Pip. Douglas is just ahead of her. He turns, smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's hope so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HIGHWAY - EVENING 28 Muriel's wheelchair is strapped to the back of the bus, which is screaming down the six-lane highway. A huge tower of luggage is piled precariously on the roof. The road appears to be complete chaos; cars, buses, even cows overtaking each other. The bus pulls into the outside lane to follow a truck which is overtaking some slower vehicles. As the truck pulls back into the inside lane, it reveals a huge truck barrelling towards them on the wrong carriageway. Norman, sitting at the front, screams his last scream...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... . U At the last minute, the bus pulls back into the inside lane. The Indians on the bus take absolutely no notice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUS - EVENING 29 Norman is grinning from ear to ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUS - DAWN 32 The sun rises. A beautiful, pearly dawn. The bus drives through the great gates of Jaipur. Below, the city shimmers in the heat. It's a magnificent sight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) What exactly is a tuk-tuk?

direction.raw_text: . JAIPUR STREET - DAWN 33 Our heroes are squashed into a pair of them, facing forwards and backwards, attempting not to swallow too much dust as they wheel crazily through the teeming morning streets of the city. They stare in amazement at the world racing past them. A scooter overtakes. A young man is driving, his girlfriend riding side-saddle on the back. Her sari billows out behind her. Douglas and Evelyn both watch her, struck by this image of beauty, youth and vitality.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREET/GARDEN PATH. MARIGOLD HOTEL - MORNING 34 The tuk-tuks have pulled up, and our travellers emerge, exhausted and dirty, staring through some garden gates at the Marigold Hotel. Once a beautiful building, once possibly even luxurious, it is clearly in the process of being given at least half the face-lift it badly needs. Parts of the building are freshly painted, some of the ornate balconies are crumbling, and one wall is clad with crazily skewed bamboo scaffolding. A huge old tree towers over an untended garden, its branches poking into the windows of the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ROOFTOP. MARIGOLD HOTEL - MORNING 34A A young man leans out from an upper balcony to see the arrival below: SONNY KAPOOR (early 20's). He deposits a paint pot and brush on a parapet, and races off across the rooftop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GARDEN PATH/COURTYARD. MARIGOLD HOTEL - MORNING 34B Dazed and horrified, the travellers wander up the pathway. A cow standing in front of them is pushed into the garden by a couple of young houseboys who then run to the tuk-tuks to collect their luggage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STAIRWAY/COURTYARD. MARIGOLD HOTEL - MORNING 34C Sonny clatters down the steep steps, and comes tearing out onto a verandah, as the travellers arrive in the courtyard below. He spreads his arms wide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Welcome to India!!! They stare up at him.

direction.raw_text: . COURTYARD/HALLWAY.BEDROOM. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 35 The courtyard is not without charm, although somewhat delapidated. A fountain at the centre does not look as if it has seen water in years, and faded awnings are strung up haphazardly. Sonny is leading Madge into the darkness of the building, towards her room.

direction.raw_text: . STREET. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAWN 47 The sun rises. A washer-man bicycles up to the hotel, a load of clean sheets balanced on his handlebars. Shopkeepers on the street are beginning to set out their wares.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREET, CENTRAL JAIPUR - DAY 50 The main road in Jaipur is chaotically busy. Crowds, bikes, cows, dust, noise, and laughter. Sonny's battered old car has broken down. Madge is in the front seat, Douglas and Jean in the back. Sonny is aiming a couple of kicks at the engine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) Can there be anywhere else in the world that is such an assault on the senses?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PUBLIC RECORDS OFFICE, JAIPUR - DAY 51 An office out of a Kafka novel; cloth bags containing files are piled all around the room, floor to ceiling. Graham is seated at a desk, in front of a sober official. He is filling in a form.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) Those who know the country of old just go about their business. But nothing can prepare the uninitiated for this riot of noise and colour ...

direction.raw_text: . STREET, CENTRAL JAIPUR - DAY 52 The chaos and din of the street is even more mind-boggling. Madge now has the bonnet up, and is studying the engine. Douglas stands in the street, staring in wonderment around him. Inside the car, Jean looks utterly traumatized, shrinking lower in her seat as a horde of kids swarm at the windows, shouting, wheedling, gesticulating. Sonny does his best to wave them away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) ... for the heat, the motion, the perpetual teeming crowds. Sonny is conducting his own personal assault on our senses

direction.raw_text: YES! A boy runs off to fetch the ball. Graham half-runs, half- walks to the other end, then turns for a second run, breathing heavily. Then walks back to the crease, gets ready for the next delivery. It's hot and he's tired, but he hasn't felt this good for years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me the ball. I can take him. He turns cheerily to Graham.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Down is where you're going, Uncle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on. Do your worst. They're both enjoying the banter, as Sanjay heads back to the beginning of his run-up, then turns and sprints in to bowl. As Graham watches Sanjay running towards him, Sanjay seems to slow, his movements becoming sluggish, never seeming to reach the crease. He looks at the faces of the other boys, frozen, waiting. The ball seems to take forever to leave Sanjay's hand. Graham steps back, completely fails to play a stroke, and is bowled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what I'm talking about! I felt the need, the need for - Graham still hasn't moved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you alright, Uncle? Graham finds his voice at last.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Yes, I'm fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREET/CALL CENTRE BUILDING - DAY 65 Suresh brakes, stops outside a glass-clad high-rise building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Suresh helps Evelyn down off the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then thank you. You're very kind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. He rides off. Evelyn looks nervously up at the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . OPERATIONS ROOM. CALL CENTRE - DAY 66 A brightly-lit open plan office on a high floor of the building. The city sprawls magnificently below. Partitions divide off the cubicles. Within them sit rows of workers, all early 20's, all with headsets clamped to their ears. As chaotic as the streets of Jaipur are, this place is immaculate, controlled and efficient. We hear snatches of what they're saying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for talking to us today We do appreciate your call while I have you on the phone, can I talk to you about our special offers . your call is important to us . now is there anything else I can help you with ... shouldn't take more than five minutes . your custom is valuable to us (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid I'll have to refer that to my supervisor just a routine security check before we start . Thank you for talking to us today Through a glass partition, Evelyn can be seen sitting at a desk, talking to someone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SUPERVISOR'S OFFICE. CALL CENTRE - DAY 67 JAY (late 20's) is talking to Evelyn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're sure I can't offer you something? We have English Breakfast Tea. Building Tea, as you call it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Builder's tea. It's called builder's tea. And no, I'm fine. Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me then. How can I help you? Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think you can. I'm sorry, I shouldn't have come. She stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saw your advertisement in the local paper, and it specifically mentioned the ability to talk to older people. But this is not what I imagined ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You came for a job?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've wasted your time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Greenslade. Everyone working here is a graduate of a good university. This is a place for ambitious people. Young people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see that. Good day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please. One second. Evelyn stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is really builder's tea?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. We dunk biscuits into it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You dunk?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It means lowering a biscuit into your tea, letting it soak in there, then trying to calculate the exact moment just before it dissolves to whip it up to the mouth, and enjoy the blissful union of biscuit and tea combined. (BEAT) It's more relaxing than it sounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps you can help us after all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . OPERATIONS ROOM. CALL CENTRE - DAY 68 A few minutes later. From the open-plan office Evelyn can be seen talking to Jay. One person watching is SUNAINA (20's). She's talking on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We do appreciate your custom, which is very important to us. And can I draw your attention to our special - But the person at the other end has hung up. Sunaina starts to dial another number. Then the clock hits 11, and a buzzer sounds. Sunaina gets up, heads for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FORECOURT. CALL CENTRE - DAY 69 Dozens of motorcycles are parked in front of the building. People are hanging around chatting and smoking. Sonny arrives on his motorcycle, a bag of marigolds strapped to the pillion seat. Sunaina, who is with some friends, spots him, comes over. She smiles as he pulls her to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I get two breaks in eight hours. Explain to me why I would want to waste one of them with you - 42. He kisses her. She kisses him back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave this place. Come and work for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't afford me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I cannot afford anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still tempting. I miss you. Am I coming round tonight?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's meet somewhere else. I will rent a hotel room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sonny, you own a hotel. It has many rooms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some of them now occupied. With actual real guests.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paying guests?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why must you nitpick? It is not an attractive quality.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It isn't? They kiss again, start to make out a bit. Then
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Sunaina! They turn to see Jay who has come out of the Call Centre.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (calling, to Sonny) You can let go of my sister now. Break's over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello Jay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sonny boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't call me that. Jay smiles, holds the door open for Sunaina.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GARDEN - EVENING 70 Jean is sitting in a chair, reading. Graham comes up the path.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening, Your Honour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Ainslie. I hope you had a good day. What did you get up to?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I started in my bedroom, where I had a lovely couple of hours giving all the cockroaches names. Then after a lunch that will long have a place in my heartburn, I came out here and stared blindly at a book waiting for someone - anyone to rescue me. And how glad I am it was you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why would you not go out? There's so much to see. Jean had hoped for some appreciation of her wit, and is floored by his question. She can hardly understand, let alone tell him, the depths of her discomfort.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Open your eyes, Mrs Ainslie. All life is here, I tell you. Jean stares at him. He goes on through the archway into the hotel. Then stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could talk to the chef, if you like. Perhaps get you some grilled chicken, plain rice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would appreciate that very much. Graham goes on in. Jean just sits there. Wishing he'd come back out again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TERRACE. MARIGOLD HOTEL - NIGHT 71 Muriel is back. She's in her chair, on the terrace outside her room. A young hotel worker, ANOKHI, brings out a tray of food to her. Muriel watches her, but Anokhi is deferential, won't meet Muriel's eyes. She puts the tray down and leaves. Muriel just sits there, glaring balefully into the night, the untouched tray of food by her side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . UPPER COURTYARD - NIGHT 72 Evelyn comes into the dining area. Graham is there, at a table in the corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening. Evelyn sits at her table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I trust you had a good day?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd rather hear about yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got a job. My first. Ever. I'm going to be a sort of cultural advisor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A role I'm sure you'll perform with great distinction. He's about to inquire further, when Evelyn sees Douglas and Jean emerge from their room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps if you wouldn't mind keeping that news to yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm flattered you shared it with me. He turns to greet the new arrivals.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening, the Ainslies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you had a good day?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spectacular. (TO GRAHAM) I went to the temple you told me about. A place of meditation and peace, quite stunning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So spiritual, I bet you hardly noticed the smell of elephant dung.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No elephants, sadly. Still none. (TO GRAHAM) I thought I might see you there. Where did you get to instead?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, where do you get to every day?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I've just finished telling Mrs Greenslade all about it. Evelyn registers the lie, but says nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure she wouldn't mind hearing it again. She waits. But Graham is as elusive as he is tactful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I talked to the chef for you. He said it will be no problem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you hear that, Douglas? Plain grilled food; manna from heaven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't have to have it too, do I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know how to thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You really should see this temple.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like that very much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But maybe take a clothes peg for your nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COURTYARD/UPPER VERANDAH, MARIGOLD HOTEL - NIGHT 73 Graham and Evelyn emerge through the arch heading for their rooms. Graham starts down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodnight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodnight to you. He seems about to say something else. She waits for a moment, then walks on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Greenslade?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Evelyn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I show you something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GRAHAM'S ROOM - NIGHT 74 Moments later. Evelyn is sitting in front of Graham's collage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I grew up here. Just a short drive away. It was a big house, and we had servants, everyone did. We knew their wives, their children. One boy, Manoj, became my friend. We played a lot of cricket together, played anything we could. And that's how it stayed for years. Until one night, he became something more. (BEAT) We had a few months, we had that. There was a weekend in Udaipur, we sat by a lake and watched the sun go down, and I remember thinking . I will never be this happy again. And I was right. Because quite suddenly it was over. We'd fallen asleep, and they found us. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For me it was bad enough. But I already knew who I was, and I think my family had guessed. For Manoj, the disgrace was absolute; a double taboo. His father was fired, they were sent away, all of them. I don't know what I could've done, but it should've been more than nothing. I put up no fight. I let it happen. (BEAT) Soon afterwards I went to England, to University. I always told myself I'd come back. But I never did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Until now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now I think .. what if I am the last person on earth he wants to see? Evelyn says nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think I can go through with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you want to see him again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Yes. Oh yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then you must.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TEMPLE/STREET. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 75 As the bell tolls, the faithful arrive at the temple for morning prayers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . UPPER VERANDAH/SERVANTS COURTYARD - DAY 75A Evelyn stands outside her room, listening to the bells, sipping a cup of tea, pensive. She looks down into a dilapidated part of the building, where the staff are housed. Women in bright saris go about their business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MURIEL'S ROOM/VERANDAH, MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 76 From her wheelchair, Muriel is re-making her bed. She tucks in a perfect hospital corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She looks up. Anokhi is on the verandah, replacing her untouched supper tray with breakfast. Anokhi is about to leave, but stops. Then she goes to fetch Muriel's jar of pickle from the windowsill, and places it on the table. Muriel watches, then wheels herself outside, looks at the tray. From outside, Sonny's voicecan be heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) And so now that we are fully operational, Mr Maruthi, it is clear that with a small injection of funds for the Phase Two Development ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GARDEN/COURTYARD. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 77 Brimming with confidence, Sonny is walking a wealthy investor, MR MARUTHI, around the grounds. Some builders are dismantling scaffolding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .. the Best Exotic Marigold Hotel can rise like a phoenix to its previous state of glory. And when I say small injection, I mean small in the sense of medium- sized. Possibly larger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This hotel was never glorious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just the phoenix part then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many rooms will there be?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Many.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A great amount. Plenty of rooms, no question. They've arrived in the courtyard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am not a details man, Mr Maruthi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nor was your father. They see Muriel on her verandah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Maruthi, I present to you one of our beloved guests. Dear Mrs Donnelly, please describe in as much detail as you desire your experience of the ambience and atmosphere of the Best Exotic Marigold Hotel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kill me. Kill me now. Sonny steers Mr Maruthi towards the reception, speaks quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The wheel is spinning. But the hamster is dead. He stops, as he sees an elegant older woman standing in the doorway. This is the redoubtable MRS KAPOOR.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mummyji! What are you doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You called. I came.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I couldn't have called. The phones don't work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's why I came.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SONNY'S OFFICE. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 78 Moments later. Sonny closes the door behind him. His mother starts going through the contents of his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who was that man out there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The contents of this desk are mine. Don't open the drawers. I must insist you don't open the drawer. Mrs Kapoor opens the drawer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me why you have come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do I need a reason to visit my favourite son?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. He is in his mansion in Delhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My second favourite.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He went to Kerala to make his fortune.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But make it, he did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As I will make mine. I have a dream, Mummyji. A most brilliant one: to out-source old age. And not just for the British. There are many other countries where they don't like old people too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your brothers own a third of the hotel each, they are entitled to a third of the profits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Success does not happen overnight, Mummyji. This is blue sky thinking, and it requires long-term strategy and patience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is your girlfriend?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I look forward to you meeting her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I look forward to you meeting the woman you will marry. She is from a good family in Delhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can marry as I choose, Mummyji. I need no permission.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I presume it is your girlfriend who teaches you such nonsense. One reason not to marry her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if I love her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An even better reason. Now send Young Wasim to the car for my luggage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He cannot carry, he has a dicky back ... wait, your luggage? How long are you staying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As long as it takes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BATHROOM. DOUGLAS AND JEAN'S. MARIGOLD HOTEL - 79 DAY Jean is looking out of her bathroom window, down into the courtyard. She sees Graham come out of his room. She turns back to the mirror, looks at herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MURIEL'S TERRACE. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 80 Near to Muriel, Anokhi is sweeping the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You won't get the dirt out like that. Anokhi just smiles at her radiantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I worked in service for years, looked after a lovely house. I kept it spotless. You need a bit more pressure on that brush. Graham walks past, on his way out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She won't speak English. She's what used to be called an Untouchable. An outcast, born below society. To a good Hindu, even her shadow is polluted. He greets Anokhi in Hindi, and heads for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where d'you go every day? Is it a woman? Nip round there for a curry and a bit of afters?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think so. I'm gay. Although nowadays more in theory than practice. Good day. He leaves. A moment later, Jean comes rushing out. Immediately she realises two things; first, that Graham has already gone. And second, that Muriel is watching her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning. Muriel says nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lovely day. Still nothing from Muriel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lovely. (BEAT) Lovely. She turns and goes back in. Muriel thinks for a while, then turns to Anokhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Long old life, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VICEROY CLUB - DAY 81 A classic colonial building, straight out of the English Raj. Madge is being shown around by an elderly secretary, MR DHARUNA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Viceroy Club was opened by the great Lord Kitchener himself, and many of the fixtures have remained unchanged since then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I see that. Perhaps you could tell me a little about the clientele? Any maharajahs? Wealthy widowed land-owners?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is not the policy of this club to divulge details of our members. They go past a very handsome older Indian man. Who radiates wealth and privilege.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Good morning, Your Excellency.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where do I sign up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The admission fee is 120,000 rupees, and thereafter 15,000 rupees each month.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wonder if I might get a little discount. Owing to my status.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your status, madam?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. One was rather hoping to fly under the radar, but one is a member of the Royal Family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which member, madam?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Princess Margaret.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is most surely an honour to meet you. And may I say how well you look. Especially taking into account that you died nine years ago. (BEAT) Your real name please, madam. And 120,000 rupees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PUBLIC RECORDS OFFICE - DAY 82 Graham comes into the chaotic office. The bookish official, MR CHIDAMBRAM, is behind the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, Sir. Did I not say that we will contact you when there is information regarding your inquiry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, you did say that. You did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: While it is most pleasant to see you, your presence does not actually accelerate our investigation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll try not to come in tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I expect I will see you then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CALL CENTRE - DAY 83 None of the operators are on the phone. Instead they are sitting in a semi-circle, looking curiously at Evelyn. Who is sitting next to Jay, a little daunted by the attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .You ring in the morning. Let's assume the person answering will be a woman. She will have had her breakfast. Tea or coffee. Semi-skimmed milk, always. If she's under 50 she'll be contemplating yet another diet, over 50 she'll have more or less given up, and be eating toast. The radio may be playing, or more likely daytime TV. A chat show, or a programme with a moderator speaking to a panel of young women whose boyfriends have all slept with their mothers. The girlfriends' mothers, I mean, not their own. Although Anyway, then the boyfriends usually come out, and everybody fights. Sunaina is in the audience. She calls out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not surprised people hang up on us. Laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the point. When the phone rings and it's this robot nobody wants a machine, but it's almost worse when it's a person behaving like one. All these sales cliches just strung together. 'Your call is important to us'. Is it? Well then sound like it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Your custom is valuable'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right. That one. Don't ever say that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Service is our middle name'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, when your middle name is
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shantanu.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which is beautiful. You people are young, vibrant, real. I'm sure the typical housewife would enjoy talking to each and every one of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her morning sounds like fun. What are you doing here? Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suppose I'm not typical anymore. (TO JAY) Is that the sort of thing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MADGE'S ROOM - EVENING 84 Madge is at her mirror, doing her make-up with great care. She looks beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VICEROY CLUB BAR - EVENING 85 Madge walks up the gravel path towards the magnificent building. She's superbly dressed, looks great. She goes up to the BARMAN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me. Would there be any wealthy single men in tonight?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is one. Madge puts some money into his breast pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps you could seat me next to him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This way, madam. He leads her along across the terrace. Madge follows, checking her hair, her breath, etc. The barman reaches an ornate suite of furniture. There's someone sitting there, his back to us, an elegant arm draped over the side of the chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His Royal Highness Prince Michael of Kent. The man rises from his chair and turns. And Madge is left staring at Norman. There's a pause. Then Madge reaches into the barman's breast pocket, and removes her money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll have that back, thank you very much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARIGOLD HOTEL - EVENING 86 Graham comes through the courtyard, heads for his room. Muriel is on her verandah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening. Muriel nods at him, and he goes on into his room. A moment later, Jean sits down next to Muriel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know where he goes. I know you know. But you won't tell me. Muriel says nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can get Hobnobs out here, you know. I know a way. (BEAT) As many as you want. Milk or plain. Long pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Public Records Office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WELL - EVENING 87 A huge construction, centuries old, with a series of steps reaching down deep into the earth, so people can climb down to get their water. Young couples sit on the steps in the evening heat, boys leap into the water. Sonny and Sunaina are watching the swimmers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My father used to bring me to this well to swim. He said the water was better, and so were the people we would meet. (BEAT) He would have liked you so much. Sunaina smiles at this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mother doesn't want us to be married.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hasn't met me yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She doesn't need to meet you Sunaina absorbs this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She knows you are not from Delhi. That you have no family money, and work in a call centre. You are a part of a new India she cannot welcome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't this where you tell her what you want?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That conversation will be easier when the hotel is a success.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you love me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have found a new investor. I am most optimistic that he will enable us to move forward with Phase Two of the Marigold Hotel
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shouldn't you finish Phase One first?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In business, if you stand still, you move backwards. No, I have that wrong. If you stand still, you are overtaken by people going the other way. Wait -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't answer the question. Do you love me?
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VICEROY CLUB BAR - NIGHT 88 Madge and Norman are sitting together. Norman is looking across at the bar, where an attractive older ex-pat lady is sitting, thus far resisting Norman's attempts to catch her eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I still think you're cramping my style.

direction.raw_text: As one would something in a museum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why must you mock? I just want to feel young again, to be needed as much as I need, if only for one night, one wonderful night. Tell me you don't know how that feels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Silence for a bit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me a minute. Then join us. She gets up, heads towards the bar. Where she sits a couple of seats away from the woman. Who is called CAROL. She sits there a moment, then sighs, and starts to talk to the barman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rejected again. Many years ago, that man over there gave me the most extraordinary night of my life. He may seem coarse and uncouth, but that only disguises a tenderness and an exquisite sensitivity to a woman's needs Norman arrives at the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Those drinks not ready yet? Madge turns to Carol.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They say patience is passion tamed. Carol smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Madge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carol.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And this . is Norman.

direction.raw_text: How do you do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carol? As in Christmas? Madge winces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suppose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great. Silence.

direction.raw_text: So what brings you to Jaipur, Carol?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Carol. What brings you to Jaipur?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I run a small boutique travel agency. But I've actually lived here all my life. My father worked in the Foreign Office. Another silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're very fit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I beg your pardon?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh god.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean you look like you keep yourself in shape. Physically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I did join a gym last year. It cost a fortune, and I didn't get any fitter. Apparently you have to actually go. Madge laughs. Norman doesn't. Then realizes that it was a joke, lets out a too-loud bray of laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And so what do you do, Norman?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. I'm
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Norman's in business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What business?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You tell her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Import-Export.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Although these days there's rather more Ex- than Im-, if you see what I mean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid I don't. Madge gets up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to splash some water on my face. Please God I drown in it. She heads for the bathroom. Norman and Carol share another silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well look, it's been lovely chatting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No it hasn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. It hasn't. But I really
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carol? She was about to go, stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can we drop all this pretence? And start again? I'm not charming. I'm not good at repartee. And I'm not a plutocrat with the sexual capacity of a rutting rhino. My name is Norman. And I'm lonely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My name is Carol. So am I.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VICEROY CLUB BAR - NIGHT 89 Minutes later. Madge comes out of the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) Day 22. Like Darwin's finches, we are slowly adapting to our environment. And when one does adapt, my god, the riches that are available. Madge looks across the bar. And is startled to see Norman and Carol chatting up a storm, laughing together. As she watches, Norman orders more drinks, then turns smiling back to his new friend. Madge walks slowly out of the bar, and into the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVELYN'S ROOM. MARIGOLD HOTEL - MORNING 90 Evelyn is at her computer, typing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) There is no past that we can bring back by longing for it
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PATH/GARDEN. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 91 Ajit is pushing Muriel down to the gate for her morning constitutional.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . only a present that builds and creates itself as the past withdraws ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SUPERVISOR'S OFFICE. CALL CENTRE - DAY 92 Jay is counting out cash into Evelyn's hand; her first paycheck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And India, like so many things in life, like life itself I suppose, is about what you bring to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . JAIPUR STREET - DAY 93 Ajit is pushing Muriel through a poor neighborhood. Muriel is looking left and right, astounded by the life she sees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's this? Where are we?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Janta Colony Kachi Basti.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened to my usual route?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anokhi has invited you to her home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't tell me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd have said no.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DOUGLAS AND JEAN'S ROOM. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 94 Jean is sitting, reading a book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you check in at the bank? Douglas emerges from the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I checked yesterday. And the day before. As requested. (BEAT) Will you be staying in again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do you ask that every morning?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I hope for a different answer. Because I think you'll be hurt if I don't. And because it's not healthy for you to spend all day and every day in the confines of the hotel. He goes back into the bathroom. Jean changes the subject.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't sleep a wink. The tap in there never stops dripping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) I talked to Young Wasim about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did he say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) No idea. It was in Hindi. Douglas comes out of the bathroom, holding the tap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought I might get it fixed myself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No time like the present. Actually I say that, but I enjoyed yesterday, and I'm optimistic about tomorrow too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish I could say the same.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So do I. He goes. Jean sits for a while, looking utterly disconsolate and lost. Then she gets up, goes over to the balcony. Down below she can see Graham leaving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LOWER COURTYARD - DAY 95 Madge is sitting on a chair. Norman arrives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Madgesty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gather the night went well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you like to hear about it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not in the least.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. Because you're going to. Two drinks, some sexually charged
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Douglas comes out, carrying a tap. And heads out of the archway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morning. Lovely day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning. They watch him leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two drinks, some sexually charged banter, and we were heading back to her place. Bidding the rickshaw farewell, I walked her to the door. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And there, my young friend, I leaned forward, and I kissed her. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that all? You didn't seal the deal?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have a date next week.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is wrong with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted to prolong the anticipation. To spend some time with the knowledge that soon I'm going to eat, drink, and laugh with someone, hold her to me, kiss her softly. Then go back to her place and get my end away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARKET - DAY 96 The market is buzzing with commerce. Evelyn is at a stall selling fabrics, talking to the vendor, AKRAM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (holding up a pashmina) Bow much for this, please Kitna
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One thousand rupees Ek hazaar
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. She reaches for her wallet. Then Douglas speaks from behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No no, forgive me. That's not how it works.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Evelyn turns, happy to see him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And to you. Sorry to butt in, but you don't ask him how much he wants, you just tell him how much you'll pay. (TO AKRAM) She'll give you two hundred. Absolutely no more, final offer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One thousand rupees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pity. (TO EVELYN) Now walk away. Walk away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know what I'm doing. Evelyn complies, and they turn and walk away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. The thing is, you see, I did actually want to buy that. To brighten up my room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll come after us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think so?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Absolutely. This is how the game is played. Just keep on walking. They push through the crowds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's playing it cool, but he'll come. They keep walking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's playing it very cool. They keep walking. Then Douglas stops. Evelyn looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's not coming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Moments later. They're back at Akram's stall. Evelyn counts out the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eight hundred and fifty, nine hundred, nine hundred and fifty, one thousand. She turns to Douglas, smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll get him next time. Then she notices something.

direction.raw_text: Why are you carrying a tap?
