result.heading: MARIGOLD HOTEL, DOUGLAS AND JEAN'S ROOM

direction.raw_text: . MARIGOLD HOTEL, DOUGLAS AND JEAN'S ROOM - DAY 97 Jean gives up on the sentence she has already read a hundred times, and snaps her book shut. She stands, then sits again. Then stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SWEEPER COLONY - DAY 98 Ajit is now pushing Muriel through a poverty-stricken slum. The people live on the streets, or in collapsing tin shacks. Everywhere there is struggle and deprivation. And yet the pervasive atmosphere is nowhere near as depressing as we would expect. The colours are bright, the smiles on the children's faces even brighter. Not that Muriel can recognise the joy, of course. She's horrified by her surroundings. And acutely aware of the stares of the slum-dwellers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ANOKHI'S HUT - DAY 98A A primitive brick and cement hut, one of the few amongst dwellings made mostly from sticks and plastic bags. A bunch of young kids are fascinated by Muriel's wheelchair, pushing it around and taking turns to sit on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ANOKHI'S HUT - DAY 99 Muriel sits on the only chair. Opposite - squashed together as if posing for a photograph - are all the generations of Anokhi's family: Anokhi herself, her husband, mother, grandmother, and several children. They all smile at Muriel. A long pause. Then Muriel turns to Ajit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How soon can I leave?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HARDWARE SHOP - DAY 100 Douglas is talking to JAMSHED, who works behind the counter. Evelyn sits outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see what I think, and of course I'm no expert, is that the valve seat has eroded, so we'll need the washer changed and a new seat re-ground. Douglas glances back at Evelyn. Who betrays not the slightest scepticism. Jamshed studies the tap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The gland nut has come away from the spindle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well of course, it could be that too. Can you fix it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not cheaply. Not cheaply. Most expensively indeed. Jamshed takes the tap to a workstation at the back, starts to fiddle with it. Douglas joins Evelyn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was in a tuk-tuk the other day, didn't seem to be taking the usual route back to the hotel. It turned out that the driver had decided to take me to another hotel, that he was sure I would prefer. And of course one wants to believe that he genuinely had my welfare at heart, and that it wasn't run bg his brother-in-law. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One wants to trust, in general, don't you think? But you never really know, do you? Jamshed stops fiddling with the tap. And takes a hammer to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The day I met my husband was the day the fair came to town. My girlfriend and I went on the carousel. Her horse was fine. But when the ride began I felt mine give a little, like it might collapse. Then these strong arms were around me, holding the horse together. And a voice in my ear said "Just trust me". And I did. Without question. Until the day he died.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How wonderful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sale of our flat went through last week. I had to sell it to pay off Hugh's debts. (BEAT) I've been forced to get a job out here. Which, in fact, I love. But even at Sonny's rates, I still couldn't make ends meet. After what my own husband did to our life savings. (BEAT) So no. You're right. You never know. Jamshed holds up the tap. Which is now in several parts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No good. You must be buying another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PATHWAY/GATE/STREET, MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 101 Jean walks down the path to the gate. She stops, looks fearfully at the chaotic sea of humanity outside. She's unable to move. Finally, she steps out. And is of course immediately assaulted by the assorted kids, beggars, street vendors, etc. As anxiety begins to engulf her, she quickens her pace, brushing through them as best she can, until she is almost running.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ANOKHI'S HUT - DAY 102 Muriel is still at the tea party. Anokhi speaks. Ajit translates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She wants to thank you for your kindness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I haven't been kind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're the only one that acknowledges her. Anokhi brings out a plate of food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tarkha dhal. Chapati.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not eating that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You will insult her very deeply if you do not. Muriel looks up. They're all still watching, waiting smiling. She looks at Anokhi's grandmother, as dignified as she is old. Muriel reaches out, takes something off the tray. And has a bite. It's not too bad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd still rather a Scotch Egg. Then she sees something through the open doorway: the children have turned her wheelchair on its side and are spinning the wheels. She's on her feet in a flash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get off! Get off it, you dirty thieving bastards! Several terrified faces turn. One little girl starts to cry. Everyone is staring at Muriel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't see. They were playing. I'm sorry. I'm sorry
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREET. JAIPUR - DAY 103 Jean is now in a tuk-tuk, lurching and weaving through the traffic, a handkerchief clasped firmly over her mouth, panic in her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STAIRCASE/CORRIDORS/OFFICE. PUBLIC RECORDS OFFICE.104
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The corridors are full of people patiently waiting their turn to grapple with a vast bureaucracy. Reaching the top of the staircase, Jean takes it all in. She walks down another corridor. Then stops. Through a doorway, she sees Graham at the desk, talking to Mr Chidambram.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I've filled out that form. I've given it to you. Many times.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a process. You are making an enquiry. For each enquiry a form must be filled in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it's the same enquiry I make every day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And therefore the same form you must fill in. Graham glances towards the doorway, catches sight of Jean. Their eyes lock, then Jean pulls back out of sight, panicked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .CORRIDOR, PUBLIC RECORDS OFFICE. JAIPUR - DAY 10414A Jean is hurrying down a corridor. Behind her, Graham emerges from a doorway, and calls to her
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Ainslie... .?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TEA ROOM. JAIPUR - DAY 106 Later. Jean and Graham are sitting in an elegant tea room. Jean is still very shaken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know how you can bear this country. What do you see that I don't?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unutterable beauty. Everywhere. In the light, the colours, the smiles, the people who see life as a privilege not a right, and so teach me something every day. The waiter brings their tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this milk pasteurized?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes madam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But that's not true, is it? You're just lying to me right now
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It'll be fine. The waiter goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a pleasant surprise to see you out and about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it? She looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. That's progress. Where were you going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To the bank. I . was going to the bank. Not that there's any reason to think something has changed. But our daughter, you see, she did promise, and one does try to remain optimistic. One has to. Otherwise
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Graham worries she might be about to break down. He reaches across the table, puts his hand on hers. She leans forward, puts her other hand over his, holds on tightly. Graham is startled. He tries gently to pull back, but she holds on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh god. Is it possible you feel the same? She brings his hand to her mouth, kisses it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The way you talk to me. Your compassion, your understanding .. the wonderful, tender consideration, it had to be more than just -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm gay. She stares at him. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As in ... happy? Graham says nothing. Jean lets go of his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I see. Of course I see. The ghastly inappropriateness of it all settles on them both.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I appear to have humiliated myself. And embarrassed you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not embarrassed. Jean smiles wanly, grateful for his lie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like I said. This country is driving me mad. (BEAT) Shall we go?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DOUGLAS AND JEAN'S ROOM. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY107 Evelyn is outside in the courtyard. We don't see Douglas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anything?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Not yet. Evelyn waits a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) One second. Another pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) (cont'd) Oh good lord.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Listen. The sound of a flowing tap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) (cont'd) And now ... The tap stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) (cont'd) No drip. He appears in the doorway, triumphant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No drip! He walks towards her, hand in the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi-five ! Evelyn just looks at him. She's never hi-fived anyone in her life. After a moment Douglas puts his hand down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've never done that before. It just seemed appropriate. Jean has appeared at the other side of the courtyard. Douglas senses her mood, moves towards her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darling!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Ainslie, how are you? Did you have a good day? Jean doesn't answer. She's staring at Douglas. Who looks so happy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me tell you about ours. Your husband of many a year, who has never even known which end of a hammer to use, has actually managed to -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have to get out of here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did you say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't stay in this country a moment longer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why ...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do excuse me. She makes a tactful exit. Jean is going past Douglas into their room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't understand
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pick a reason. Pick ten. The climate, the squalor, the poverty She goes past him into their room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DOUGLAS AND JEAN'S ROOM - CONTINUOUS 108 JEAN . we should never have come. This whole trip is a grotesque fantasy. It's time to go home. Jean starts to pack. Irrationally, compulsively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's paying for the tickets?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (not hearing him) Look at us. A group of self- deluding old fossils traipsing around as if it's our bloody gap year. Humiliating ourselves
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not us, we can't pay. And I don't see you asking our friends
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .. We should just face up to the truth. That we're all old, we're all past it. That's the real truth, the raw, unvarnished fact of the matter. All we're good for now is the beige bloody bungalow with the sodding panic button in the sodding corner ... She stops packing, and subsides onto the bed, crying quietly. Nobody speaks for a while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We just have to make the best of it, darling. I really think that's the best thing to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, well. When I want your opinion, I'll give it to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MEEHAR CLINIC - MORNING 109 An impossibly small roadside clinic. Norman is sitting there, the only man in three rows of brightly dressed women.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: comes out of the consulting area.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr John Smith. No response. The doctor looks at Norman, who has forgotten his own alias.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Mr John Smith? Norman jumps up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right! Me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARKET/OPERATIONS ROOM. CALL CENTRE - DAY 110 Sonny is at the flower market, sitting on his motor bike, waiting for the flower vendor to tie up his bundle of marigolds. He's on his phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on. Pick up pick up pick up. The phone is answered at the other end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sunaina, I must see you. I must. If I cannot hold your body against mine, I swear I will go mad. We cut to the call centre. It's not Sunaina on the phone, but Jay, who is standing next to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I yearn for you, I burn for you, I -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think it's my sister you're burning for there, Sonny boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Jay. Thank you. Jay hands the phone to Sunaina.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Private line, Sunaina. Do those words mean nothing to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He took the phone. What could I do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I miss you. I miss you every moment. Come and see me. Tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I cannot tonight. It is my parents 25th wedding anniversary. Tell your mother that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come after. Come late
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll be asleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll be asleep. But i can wake you in that special way...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You will sneak in?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not ashamed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neither am I. Absolutely not. There is no shame. You do not have to sneak. (BEAT) All the same, if you did want to be very quiet, and not let anyone see you, it couldn't hurt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONSULTING ROOM - DAY 111 Norman is talking to DR RAMA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm worried there's no lead in my pencil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . I don't know what that means.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No snap in my celery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm still not quite with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I plan to party hearty tonight, but I can't guarantee that my love gun will fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Smith -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will the lance dance, and the trouser lion roar?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is your problem?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know if I can still have sex.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not a young man anymore, doctor. And I'm a little bit scared. Truth be told, I'm a lot scared.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long since you've been with a woman?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's today?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Monday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Six years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got some pills that'll help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SERVANTS COURTYARD. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 112 The back of the hotel, where Sonny envisages his Phase Two development. Very dilapidated. Anokhi is cleaning pots. Young Wasim sits in the corner. Ajit has just wheeled Muriel into the courtyard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted to tell you something... Anokhi looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell her. Tell her I was glad to come, glad she invited me. Ajit translates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Glad to meet her family. Her grandmother. Her kids. Ajit translates. Anokhi speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She asks if you have children?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I looked after somebody else's. Ajit translates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This one family, years I was with them. I ran the house, looked after the money, did it all, cared for them like they were my own. Ajit starts to translate. But Muriel doesn't wait.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the mistake, see. You don't want to get like that, to start feeling part of something. One day they decided I needed some help. I was grateful, I tried to teach her. Not just the books, but how to crisp up the bacon like the gentleman preferred it, the way the little one liked to have her hair brushed. The things you only know if you care. But then they said I was no longer useful to them. Thanked me for my service. As if that's all it was. (BEAT) I got a flat in the end. I'm the only one in the building not a foreigner. More Indians there than here! But before I came to this place, my biggest problem was what to do with all the time I had. Because that flat's so small, I can have the whole place spotless in half an hour. And then what am I supposed to do for the rest of the day? There's silence for a bit. Then Ajit speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you want me translate that as well? Muriel smiles. It's the first time we've seen this. Muriel stops, thrusts something into Ajit's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give her these.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Ajit hands Anokhi what Muriel gave him: a packet of Chocolate Hobnobs. This time it's Muriel who cannot meet Anokhi's eye. Tries to hide her desire to leave. Ajit turns her chair and pushes her away. Over this, the sound of singing
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ROOFTOP. MARIGOLD HOTEL - EVENING 113 Norman's on his rooftop, under the primitive spout of water that passes as his shower. Hanging from a nail in the wall, the battery radio is pumping out a bizarre Indian cover version of the Chic song "Le Freak". Norman is naked, and singing along lustily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aaaaaah, freak out! Le freak, c'est chic .. Aaaah, freak out! Feet slapping in the soapy water, he performs a nifty disco move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SONNY'S OFFICE. MARIGOLD HOTEL - EVENING 114 Sonny is in his office, going through the accounts. There's a strange ringing somewhere nearby. He pays no attention, then stops and thinks for a moment. Then realises what it is. He sweeps the pile of papers off the desk, starts frantically looking for the telephone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . UPPER COURTYARD. MARIGOLD HOTEL - EVENING 115 Graham and Evelyn are having drinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been getting out and about as much as I can, but I feel I've hardly scratched the surface. And of course I'd love to see Udaipur. The lake you talked about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd love to take you. Perhaps - He breaks off. Douglas and Jean have come in. Jean looks rather desperate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . An awkward moment. Graham stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening, Mrs Ainslie. Please allow me. He pulls a chair out for her. She shoots him a look of passionate gratitude for his exquisite sensitivity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're very kind. But I rather think I'll turn in early. Goodnight everyone. She goes into her room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COURTYARD. MARIGOLD HOTEL - EVENING 116 Muriel is sitting outside her room, doing the crossword. Madge is coming through the arch, stops dead. Norman is standing in front of her, on his way out. He looks transformed. And rather handsome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not worried about the danger of having sex at your age? Norman shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If she dies, she dies. He leaves. Sonny sprints into the courtyard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Progress, Mrs Donnelly, Mrs Hardcastle! The wheel is turning most assuredly in our favour! He shoots up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . UPPER COURTYARD. MARIGOLD HOTEL - EVENING. 117 Douglas, Graham and Evelyn are looking at the menu. Sonny bursts in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Dashwood! Everybody! Great news!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it, Sonny?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are working, they are working!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is great news. What are working?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The telephones of the Marigold Hotel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, congratulations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. I must tell everybody. I must tell my mother! He runs off. Comes back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh wait. You have a phone call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREET, POOR NEIGHBOURHOOD. JAIPUR - EVENING 118 Graham, Evelyn, and Douglas are walking quickly up a quiet street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a false alarm. There's no way they could find anything in that office. They probably just picked an address at random, just to keep me off their backs. I'm sure that's what happened. It's going to be nothing. Don't you think it's going to be nothing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think you should knock on the door and see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Yes I should. (BEAT) Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOUSE - EVENING 119 Some men sit under a tree, playing cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Across the street, Graham approaches a house. At a polite distance, Evelyn and Douglas wait. Graham knocks at the open door. A woman, GAURIKA, appears. She stares at Graham.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry to disturb you so late. My name is Graham Dashwood. A long time ago I -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know who you are. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am afraid I don't know you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am Gaurika. The wife of Manoj.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (after a fraction of a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm very pleased to meet you. And if you could, if you would tell him that I called around, I'd appreciate that very much,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He breaks off. She's walked past him, looking to the other side of the road. He turns to look at the men playing cards. Gaurika calls in Hindi. A beautiful-looking man looks up. MANOJ. He looks across at the house. Stands up slowly as Graham walks across the street towards him. Graham reaches him. The two men just stand there for a moment. Then they hug very tightly. From the steps of the house, Gaurika watches. Evelyn looks at her, fascinated. Across the street, Manoj and Graham are still holding each other, unable to let go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREET - NIGHT 120 Douglas and Evelyn are walking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a tiny bit sloshed) (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First time going in to London with my dad, on his commute... He'd always been so extraordinary to me, so unique. But there he was standing on the station platform, utterly indistinguishable from all the other men in suits. And then of course a few years later I was one of them... Hated my job. Hated it. (BEAT) Sorry, talking too much. Blame a good dinner out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was she thinking?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I beg your pardon?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His wife. Manoj's wife. She knew who Graham was. Had he told her? (BEAT) D'you think we'll find out tomorrow?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not me, I'm heading up to the Badi Mahal Palace. Very excited, been reading all about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would, if I could remember a word. Evelyn laughs. Then Douglas suddenly grabs her. And pulls her out of the way of a motor bike, zooming past them. Sunaina hasn't realised she nearly hit them, and powers on towards the Marigold. Douglas and Evelyn stand for a moment, startled, holding each other. Something passes between them that embarrasses them both. Then they part quickly, guiltily. They're outside a small restaurant, and with exquisite timing, a group of musicians start to play a romantic tune.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come, please. Nice meal, please...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've eaten, thank you... They continue on their way. Slightly further apart than before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARIGOLD HOTEL - NIGHT 121 It's the middle of the night, and everything's quiet Or as quiet as it can be in the middle of the usual night-time Indian cacophony. Sunaina parks her bike outside the hotel, goes on in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM, MARIGOLD HOTEL - NIGHT 122 Sonny is sleeping peacefully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COURTYARD, MARIGOLD HOTEL - NIGHT 123 Sunaina moves across the courtyard. Not sneaking, exactly. But making no sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM, MARIGOLD HOTEL - NIGHT 124 Sonny sleeps on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CORRIDOR, MARIGOLD HOTEL - NIGHT 125 Sunaina is definitely sneaking now. She aims down the passage towards Sonny's room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM, MARIGOLD HOTEL - NIGHT 126 Sonny stirs, but doesn't wake up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM, MARIGOLD HOTEL - NIGHT 127 Sunaina comith esno te bedroom. She takes off her clothes. And climbs, naked, into bed beside the sleeping figure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM, MARIGOLD HOTEL - NIGHT 128 A loud scream. In a different bed, in a different room, Sonny wakes up. And remembers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM, MARIGOLD HOTEL - NIGHT 129 It's Sunaina that's screamed. Because she's in bed with Madge. Who couldn't be happier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A midnight booty call. How utterly marvellous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CORRIDOR, MARIGOLD HOTEL - NIGHT 130 Sonny hares out of his temporary bedroom, and races down the corridor, towards Madge's room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM, MARIGOLD HOTEL - NIGHT 131 Sunaina has jumped out of the bed and across the room, grabbing one of Madge's generous scarves to cover her nakedness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so sorry, I'm so sorry . I don't know what your name is, but I'm incredibly sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be. Most action I've had in weeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you could just please not
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sonny bursts in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do not worry, Mrs Hardcastle! I can explain each and every thing! Hesees Sunaina.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my god you are naked. He turns to Madge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Hardcastle, I must apologise with deep and profound sincerity -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How could you not tell me you weren't in your room!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Sunaina, to you too I must apologise with equally deep and profound sincerity. Now go. Get out. Quickly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going. Just let me get dressed, and -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No no, quicker than that. You must leave, before - MrsKapoor flings open the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is going on here? Who screamed? She sees the nearly-naked Sunaina.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) No no no no no. No! This is a respectable hotel, not a brothel. (TO SUNAINA) You, get out. (TO MADGE) And Mrs Hardcastle, I expected better of you. Actually, this is exactly what I expected of you, but nevertheless -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Kapoor, I'm Sunaina.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Since I will not be paying for your services, your name is of no interest to me. (BEAT) How do you know mine? Sunaina is shocked to realise that Mrs Kapoor doesn't know her name. Sonny steps forward reluctantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because this . is my Sunaina.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girl who my son described as not too modern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is getting interesting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me, please. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Is there anyone in this building you haven't slept with?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mummyji, do not get the wrong idea. Sunaina was not here to be with Mrs Hardcastle. She was here to have sex with me! Mrs Kapoor turns to Sunaina. Who is speechless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the sort of woman you are. OK. Each to her own. But do not ever try and tell me that you are suitable wife for my son. (BEAT) Find your clothes and go. I don't expect to see you again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GARDEN/PATHWAY. MARIGOLD HOTEL - NIGHT 132 Sunaina is leaving the hotel, angry and humiliated. Evelyn and Douglas are coming up the path.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sunaina? And now Sunaina is even more humiliated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREET. MARIGOLD HOTEL - NIGHT 132A Sunaina roars away on her scooter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREET. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAWN 133 The same street. The sun is just coming up, and traders are setting up their stalls, spreading their wares on rugs on the ground. One trader is unloading some fruit. A few guava roll off the edge of his wagon. Someone picks them up for him. It's Graham, who smiles as he puts them back. The trader gives him a fresh one. Graham takes it, and walks on, munching the delicious fruit. A contented man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GARDEN. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAWN 134 Norman is sitting on a stone bench under a spreading tree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) How did it go? Norman turns, to see Graham standing above him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have seen the top of the mountain. And it is good. Graham nods, sits down next to him. They gaze out at the waking city.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saw someone yesterday, a man I hadn't seen for many years. A man I've loved all my life. Norman is a bit startled by this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A man... .?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carry on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling, unperturbed) I didn't know how he'd been in the meantime, didn't want to guess. I brought disgrace upon him and his family, and imagined he might hate me for it. (BEAT) But we talked all night. He's been happy. He's led a peaceful life, married to a woman who understood him and loved him nonetheless. But he's never forgotten me. That's what he said. (BEAT) I asked his forgiveness anyway. He said he had nothing to forgive me for. That instead I should forgive myself. (BEAT) All that time. All that time I believed I'd sentenced him to a life of shame. When I was the one in prison. (BEAT) But not any more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Silence for a while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Top of the mountain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Norman smiles, then stands and goes on inside. Graham settles back into his chair, looks out at the world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not any more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COURTYARD/VERANDAH, MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAWN 135 Norman comes into the courtyard. Madge, sipping from a cup of chai, calls down from her verandah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How was the night?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rather special. He leaves. Madge just stares after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STAIRCASE. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAWN 136 Norman on the stairs to his room. He stops, catches his breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GARDEN. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAWN 137 Graham is watching a stunningly beautiful bird. A snow crane; white and magnificent. It's on the grass in front of him. Then it opens its huge wings, takes off. And flies up into the bright blue sky. It's an extraordinary sight. As Graham watches the snow crane swoop and dip, it appears suddenly to slow and stall, until it seems to hang in the air, almost motionless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ROOFTOP. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAWN 138 Norman crosses the rooftop to his bedroom. He comes inside, sits on the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GARDEN, MARIGOLD HOTEL - MORNING 139 Graham is still sitting in the garden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) You're back. He doesn't turn round. Evelyn has come out to the garden. She goes over to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's been rather an extraordinary night all round. First tell me your news, and then - She breaks off. Graham is dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COURTYARD. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 139A EVELYN (V.0.) Day 45. Of course it was inevitable. Put enough old people in the same place, it won't be too long before one of them goes... Jean, Douglas, Madge, Norman and Muriel shocked and sobered
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COUNTRYSIDE - DAY 140 A train is crossing the endless fields.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TRAIN - DAY 141 Evelyn stares out of the window. Madge, Norman, Douglas and Jean are behind her. Opposite sits Manoj. Evelyn turns to look at him, and at Gaurika, Manoj's wife, who sits beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) We all know it'll happen, but few of us know when. Graham died of a heart attack, evidently not his first. So he had a better idea than most what was coming, he just neglected to tell us. His prerogative.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LAKE - DAWN 142 Three white vehicles are driving across a narrow causeway, which barely rises above the surface of the lake. They seem to be floating. Clouds of dust billow behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) There was talk of sending the body home, but Manoj felt he should have a Hindu burial. At the place they had visited together. Not a holy place. Although for them perhaps it was.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL PYRE, RUINS - DAY 143 A ruined garden, surrounded by the waters of the lake, crumbling pillared porticoes and arches. What must once have been a royal retreat is now long abandoned and overgrown. Graham's friends stand watching the pyre, transfixed by the flames. Manoj, dressed in white, stands with Gaurika. He recites a Hindi prayer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) A body takes a long time to be consumed. Many hours for the mourners to remember their dead. The fire must be lit at dawn, and by sunset, there must be nothing left but ash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LAKESIDE - SUNSET 144 Stripped to the waist, Manoj walks into the water, holding a bowl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) Where do our souls go? is that all of us that is left behind? Perhaps the most we can ask is that when we do shuffle off, we do so knowing that we were loved Manoj pours Graham onto the water. The ashes shim r and dance, caught in the gentle currents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SERVANT'S GARDEN. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 145 Muriel and Anokhi are in the servants' garden. Young Wasim sits silently in the corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So there's a process, they call it pickling. I have no idea what it is, or how they do it, but whoever invented it was a smart man. But the real genius was the one who introduced an onion into the system. That I could never have thought of.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Ajit looks at her, ready to translate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, forget it. Muriel is looking out at the yard. She sees Mrs Kapoor, talking to some surveyors. They're mapping out the building. Mrs Kapoor sees Muriel watching her, comes over to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Donnelly, what are you doing here? You should not be here, talking with this one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm helping her clean. If these pots get any dirtier, you'll have to serve the food with penicillin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have other rooms. Go to one of them instead. While this is still a hotel. She turns back to the surveyors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's her problem? What's happening here? Ajit can't answer. But he knows a man who can. He points to Young Wasim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can tell you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ROOFTOP BAR, BHARATPUR PALACE HOTEL. UDAIPUR - 146 EVENING A stunning view over the city. Madge is having a drink with Norman. Douglas is sitting on the wall, but keeps looking down towards the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When someone dies, you think about your own life. And in my case, there is less of it in front of me than behind. And I don't want to grow older. I don't want to be condescended to, ignored and marginalised by society. To become peripheral to the action. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (coat' d) I don't want to be the first person let off the plane in a hostage crisis. They laugh together. And don't even see Douglas go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LANDING. BHARATPUR PALACE HOTEL - EVENING 147 The landing is large, and open to the sky. Evelyn has just come up the stairs to go to her room. She's leaning against the stone baluster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wondered where you'd been. Evelyn turns. Douglas is on the stairs above her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're all up top, having a drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I went to see Gaurika. Manoj's wife. I wanted to ask her what she knew. And the answer was that she knew everything, that he'd loved another man, and always would. He told her when the marriage was arranged. (BEAT) They had no secrets from each other, none. Suddenly she's crying. Unable to stop. Douglas puts his arms around her, and holds her to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that's right, don't you see? That must be right. Because what is the point of a marriage in which nothing is shared? Her words hang in the air. They stand there for a moment. Jean has come out of her room, and stands there, watching them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Greenslade, might I have my husband back now? They spring apart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Douglas? She walks off back into the room. Douglas turns to Evelyn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, of course.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive me. Evelyn goes quickly to her room, leaving him standing there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DOUGLAS AND JEAN'S ROOM - EVENING 148 Douglas closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was upset.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spare me your explanations. D'you think I'm jealous?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't see why else you would have embarrassed me. And Evelyn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were already doing a perfectly good job of embarrassing yourself. Can you imagine how ghastly it's been for everyone to watch you mooning around after that simpering doe- eyed ex-housewife, taking advantage of her loneliness and -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God, can you hear yourself? Can you? Do you have any idea what a terrible person you've become? Jean is stunned into silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All you give out is this endless negativity, a refusal to see any kind of light and joy even when it's right in your face, and a desperate need to squash any sign of happiness in me or anyone else .. it's a wonder I don't fling myself at the first kind word or gesture that comes my way. But I don't. Out of some dried-out notion of loyalty and respect, neither of which I ever bloody get in return.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . There's a long silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I checked my emails. This came. She hands him a piece of paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ROOFTOP BAR. BHARATPUR PALACE HOTEL - EVENING 149 Evelyn comes onto the terrace, and heads for Madge and Norman. She picks up Madge's glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you alright?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just need some water. She drains the glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was a gin and tonic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I know that now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a disaster.

direction.raw_text: Then we must treat it just the same as we would treat a triumph, is that not what your Mr Kipling tells us? Although of course, here we have a problem. Because

Sonny is on his bike, Sunaina riding side-saddle on the back. They're speeding through the city. Sonny rockets through an arch way up a side street, is confronted by a huge traffic jam. The Ganeshi procession is bringing everything to a standstill. He does a U-turn, speeds off back the way they came.

direction.raw_text: My loss, evidently. (BEAT) I'm not sure what I should do. Nothing here has quite worked out as I hoped.

direction.raw_text: If you'll excuse me, someone's waiting to help me make mango chutney. Why did no one tell me about that stuff?

direction.raw_text: . AIRPORT ROAD. JAIPUR - EVENING 175A Jean sits in the rickshaw, surrounded by her luggage, carried by Ifti's strong legs towards her future.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) Day 51. The only real failure is the failure to try.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVELYN'S ROOM, MARIGOLD HOTEL - EVENING 175B Evelyn is at her computer typing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) And the measure of success is how we cope with disappointment. As we always must.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREET, CENTRAL JAIPUR - NIGHT 175C Douglas, still holding his suitcase, is surrounded by Ganeshi drummers, silhouetted against the lights of the city. The sound fades as he disappears into the celebration, and is replaced by the gentle sound of temple bells, ringing for morning prayers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) We came here, and we tried. All of us, in our different ways.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVELYN'S ROOM, MARIGOLD HOTEL - MORNING 176 Evelyn is still sitting, fully dressed in her room. She's been up all night. Her alarm clock buzzes. She turns it off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVELYN'S TERRACE, MARIGOLD HOTEL - MORNING 177 Evelyn comes out of her room, walks across the terrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COURTYARD, MARIGOLD HOTEL - MORNING 178 EVELYN (V.0.) Some achieved more than others. but we did our best. Nothing else matters. Evelyn walks through the courtyard, and on out of the hotel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GARDEN/PATHWAY, MARIGOLD HOTEL - MORNING 179 Evelyn walks down the path towards the street. Then Douglas comes through the gate, with his suitcase. They stand there, looking at each other for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning.

direction.raw_text: I had quite an interesting night, actually. I met the same taxi driver, but this time I let him take me to his brother's hotel. Which turned out to be less of a hotel, and more of a brothel, really. They gave me this pipe, said it was apple tobacco, but that's not what we called it when I was a student. So I made my excuses and left, wanted some time to think. This city at night is extraordinary. (BEAT) Of course the apple tobacco helped. (BEAT) Guess what? I finally saw an elephant. Silence for a bit.

direction.raw_text: . MARKET, JAIPUR - DAY 180 EVELYN (V.0.) Perhaps it's true: we don't stop playing because we grow old, we grow old because we stop playing. Douglas is haggling with a motorbike mechanic. He seems to be having more success with the price than in earlier days.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ROOFTOP, MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 180A Carol is lying on Norman's bed, reading a book, while he washes his socks in a bucket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) (CONT'D) All we really know about the future is that it will be different.

direction.raw_text: . VICEROY CLUB. JAIPUR - DAY 181 Madge is chatting vivaciously to someone. It's the elegant older man we saw earlier. And he seems utterly smitten.

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) (CONT'D) So we must celebrate the changes.
